dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey B, you know, I was just reading this article, and it's pretty wild. It says central banks, like, the Fed, ECB, BoJ... they're pumping about 22 trillion dollars into the financial system.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey B, you know, I was just reading this article, and it's pretty wild. It says central banks, like, the Fed, E C B, B O J... they're pumping about twenty two trillion dollars into the financial system.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The roughly $22 trillion of liquidity the Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, Bank of Japan and Bank of England are pumping into financial systems matches the size of annual U.S. output.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Twenty-two trillion? Wow. That's like, uh, the size of the entire annual U.S. output, isn't it? And, you know, they're saying that might just be the start.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Twenty-two trillion? Wow. That's like, uh, the size of the entire annual U S output, isn't it? And, you know, they're saying that might just be the start.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The roughly $22 trillion of liquidity the Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, Bank of Japan and Bank of England are pumping into financial systems matches the size of annual U.S. output. That may be just the start, as the odds of new outbreaks threaten to pulverize demand from China to Brazil.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly! And the big worry is this idea of a "lost decade" for global growth. Like, setting back living standards way more than people realize.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly! And the big worry is this idea of a lost decade for global growth. Like, setting back living standards way more than people realize.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its also a reason to worry about a lost decade for global growth that sets back living standards more than economists and investors realize.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which, um, naturally makes you think of Japan, right? They've been living with deflation for like, two decades now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, um, naturally makes you think of Japan, right? They've been living with deflation for like, two decades now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As if often the case in gloomy economic moments, attention turns to Japan, where deflation has been the reality for two decades now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Even though their central bank, the BOJ, has been trying everything since 2013, with upward price pressures... but that deflationary mindset is still really strong.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Even though their central bank, the B O J, has been trying everything since twenty thirteen, with upward price pressures... but that deflationary mindset is still really strong.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though the BOJ made some progress since 2013 generating upward price pressures, the deflationary mindset Governor Haruhiko Kuroda sought to change is reasserting itself.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And what's interesting, Host_A, is the article points out *why* all that epic easing, I mean, by the third-largest economy, hasn't re-ignited inflation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And what's interesting, Host A, is the article points out why all that epic easing, I mean, by the third-largest economy, hasn't re-ignited inflation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's the key. They pioneered quantitative easing, zero interest rates since '99... but, like, it didn't really work the way they wanted.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's the key. They pioneered quantitative easing, zero interest rates since ninety nine... but, like, it didn't really work the way they wanted.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since 1999, zero interest rates have been the norm in Japan, which pioneered quantitative easing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And in the longer run, it actually made things worse. The article really hammers home this point about how it exacerbates inequality.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And in the longer run, it actually made things worse. The article really hammers home this point about how it exacerbates inequality.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yet, as Japan shows, audacious monetary easing tends to make things worst in the longer run. The problem: how countries letting central banks lead rescue efforts exacerbates inequality.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, like, after 2008, when the Fed's QE helped people with, um, significant assets thrive, while everyone else struggled?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, like, after two thousand eight, when the Fed's Q E helped people with, um, significant assets thrive, while everyone else struggled?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Fed shouldve learned this lesson after 2008. At the time, then-Chairman Ben Bernanke embraced QE to save an economy essentially hurtling off a cliff. That life-support effort stuck around too long. The longer it persisted, the more ultra-easy policies morphed into a regressive wealth transfer to the haves from the have-nots. Those with sizable property and asset investments thrived. Everyone else struggled.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Precisely! Japan, once known for egalitarianism, saw QE enrich the land and asset-owning class at the expense of the masses. It's a huge wealth transfer.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely! Japan, once known for egalitarianism, saw Q E enrich the land and asset-owning class at the expense of the masses. It's a huge wealth transfer.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The same is true of Japan, an economy once prized for egalitarianism. Though rising competition from China is depressing wages, QE policies enriched the land- and asset-owning class at the expense of the masses.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And it led to this concept of "zombie-fication" for companies, right? Just, like, staying afloat but not really innovating or competing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it led to this concept of zombie-fication for companies, right? Just, like, staying afloat but not really innovating or competing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over time, though, its led to the zombie-fication of so much of Japans entire economy. All that free money took the onus off CEOs to raise their competitive games. Companies came to depend on loans to stay afloat, while dwindling profits make it hard to cover debt payments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. Cash hoarding, lack of confidence... it just, uh, took the onus off CEOs to raise their game. Instead of structural reforms, they just got free money.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. Cash hoarding, lack of confidence... it just, uh, took the onus off C E O s to raise their game. Instead of structural reforms, they just got free money.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the first quarter, for example, cash hoarding among companies rose to $4.5 trillion, an eye-popping 89% of GDP. ... Because banks, companies and households lack confidence about the future, little lending and borrowing takes place. ... All that free money took the onus off CEOs to raise their competitive games.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, now you see the U.S., eurozone, UK, they're all kind of on a similar trajectory, with central banks acting like ATMs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, now you see the U S, eurozone, U K, they're all kind of on a similar trajectory, with central banks acting like A T M s.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The U.S., eurozone and U.K. are on a similar trajectory as the central banks play the role of mere ATMsa $22 trillion ATM among just the G4 monetary authorities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, a $22 trillion ATM. And the article warns this largess isn't going to increase productivity or narrow the rich-poor divide.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, a twenty two trillion dollar A T M. And the article warns this largess isn't going to increase productivity or narrow the rich-poor divide.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: All that largess wont increase Americas productivity or narrow the rich-poor divide.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It won't make Europe more innovative or, like, modernize the UK's manufacturing. It's just... propping things up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It won't make Europe more innovative or, like, modernize the U K's manufacturing. It's just... propping things up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It wont make Europe more innovative or get it closer to the fiscal union needed to balance regional growth. It wont modernize the U.K. manufacturing sector.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It might break the global economy's fall temporarily, but, um, with no vibrant export destination, it's just accelerating wealth trickling up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It might break the global economy's fall temporarily, but, um, with no vibrant export destination, it's just accelerating wealth trickling up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: All that liquidity might break the global economys fall. But with no vibrant export destination and few true reformers in government, all that cash is likely to accelerate the trickling up of wealth away from middle- and lower-income households.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, this "free money" everyone's talking about... it actually comes at a pretty huge cost, then.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, this free money everyone's talking about... it actually comes at a pretty huge cost, then.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Free money is coming at a huge cost.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: A massive one, Host_A. A massive one.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A massive one, Host A. A massive one.
